title: Exceeded my expectations
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 19, 2020
body: This is truly an amazing projector.  It is a very handy all in one device. We have a basement home theater with an old 720p Panasonic and while I still consider the picture quality to be good for its resolution, it is a large machine and fixed in position because it needs to be wired for everything. I have been wanting to both upgrade our resolution and get something portable that can function as more of a stand alone device. This projector has met and exceeded my expectations. It is the first projector I have tried that outperforms my my aging one.The picture quality is incredible in its brightness, high contrast ratio and resolution. That was surprising to me for such a compact device. The picture quality through the apps or connected device is crisp and bright. It is a great native 1080p projector and even supports 4K ultra HD. It is best in a dark room but still bright easy to see in low lighting with connected power. When I cast my android device through the google home app, the picture is slightly lower resolution but still good. The convenience of being able to cast from a phone, or other connected device outweighs any downgrade in resolution for me. To get the higher resolution, one can easily connect a portable device, like a fire TV stick and keep that portability and clarity.The built in Harmon Kardon speaker has great sound quality, very loud and full sound. I do not find that I need additional speakers to be able to enjoy a movie. For when I do want to use surround sound, I do love the convenience of having Bluetooth connectivity, which allows me to use a Bluetooth speaker system and not have wires all over the place. Bluetooth pairing was straightforward and quick for me to set up. There is also an auxiliary connection for sound.It really is a great stand-alone device, especially with its built in battery that allows it to be used without connected power. I should note that the picture is slightly less bright on battery power to conserve battery, but not much. The battery life is sufficient for me to be able to enjoy a movie, which will be handy for when we use it outside. I absolutely love the quick autofocus and vertical keystone correction. It ensures that my projected image is crisp and clear at all times. Horizontal keystone correction is done manually, but easy to do if it is needed. I tend to centrally locate the projector on a table in front on me and find the horizontal correction unnecessary. Since the cooling fan is so quiet while it is running, there is no distraction from fan noise, having the projector close by.I am finding it to be very user-friendly with a variety of ways to use it. Being a smart projector it has several apps like Google Play, Disney, etc. available for direct streaming. Basically anything you can view on a chrome cast device, you can access with this projector. Netflix, Prime and Hulu are not yet directly available, however, these can be accessed easily through either screen casting or with a connected HDMI device like a fire TV stick. They are working on the licensing to make those extensions available. The projector is also able to play from portable hard drives if you have downloaded content.Overall, I am thrilled with this projector. The performance is incredible and it has exceeded my expectations.

title: Should've been a Home run but it was far from it.
date: Reviewed in the United States on May 7, 2020
body: Here are my Pros: Overall you cannot get all these features in any other projector at this price point. Picture quality is fantastic you can definitely see that it is 1080p. I love the autofocus and the vertical and horizontal keystone as I project from the side onto the wall.All that being said here are my Cons: The "high quality Harmon Kardon" do not offer very much volume, the sound is flat and tingy when it tries to get to higher volumes. I've had sound drop issues as well.The picture has been great when it works. I have had multiple instances where the entire image pixelates and the image drops out. On high brightness the picture is extremely Green in color. Due to the lumens on this protector it struggles with dim scenes in movies.I hooked up my Roku stick with this projector and to my surprise there is no sound out. The only reason I hooked up my Roku was for the lack of support of Netflix which can still be worked around through other apps on Android TV that is built into the MOGO Pro.In my opinion at this price point the issues with sound and picture should be unacceptable. I'll be returning this and continuing my search for a projector with similar features.Update: I've messaged Xgimi and their techs have solved the problem with the sound drop out and the problem of no sound from my Roku Express. This is good except that Bluetooth is garbled when connected to a Bluetooth speaker or when using Bluetooth with the HDMI port. There are MANY remaining issues with this projector. The screen pixelation that occurs on YouTube, Xgimi acknowledged this was a problem and said it will be in a patch in the future. I didn't get a timeline for that so in the meantime I'll just use the Roku for YouTube. I was going to keep this but I kept running into more software snags Xgimi said they were aware and that it would be in an upcoming update but couldn't give me an estimated timeline for when I should expect it to be fixed. In addition there are issues with Hulu playback where the image is frozen but there is still sound playing. My question is, why do they advertise that Hulu, YouTube and Netflix works when they clearly don't. Don't advertise if the experience isn't available.Get an Epson 2100 or 2150. It's no portable but I got mine refurbished from Amazon for less than the Xgimi MOGO Pro. There quality is leaps and bounds above Xgimi. I plug in my Roku express and I'm blown away by the projector colors and brightness. This is bulkier and it's not smart but for the picture that it puts out 1000% better than the MOGO Pro. Also Google is going to be releasing its own android TV dongle later this year. Then my Epson 2100 will be essentially the same as Xgimi except better because it will support every app in the play store.

body: I have really enjoyed using this projector. It is bright, sharp, has Android TV, is compact & portable, and just fun to use. I have used this for a couple of weeks, and have some thoughts. I was able to get a 10% coupon by signing up for XGIMI's mailing list, and for $500, this is a great buy.The Pros:-The MoGo Pro is very small and portable without compromising on image quality. The battery life is also decent.-The automatic focus is really nice to have and saves me time and sanity. (This is with the power cable connected)-It has a tripod mount on the bottom, which allows me to throw this on either a Mini Tripod (I used the Manfrotto Pixi) or a full-size tripod. This was almost a necessity for me.-While I prefer Roku, the Android TV interface has pretty much everything that you will need. I really enjoyed using the Plex app with my own content.-The remote is light, easy to use, and feels good in the hand.-It has an audio out jack if you want to hook it up to a home theater system, an external speaker, or some headphones with no noticeable lag.-The projector has Bluetooth, and I was able to connect my Bluetooth headphones, a Bluetooth speaker, and even a Bluetooth keyboard.-I was able to load music and videos on a thumb drive, plug it into the USB port, and play it on the projector.-The projector came in a double-layered package with Silica Gel and high-quality foam. It should make it to you in one piece.The "Okays":-The sound quality and volume of the built-in speaker is pretty good, but if there will be much background noise, or the sound needs to travel a long distance, I would recommend connecting an external speaker.-It didn't include batteries for the remote, so make sure that you have a couple of AAA's lying around...-On this projector, a 100" image is produced from 8-9 feet away.The Cons:-The battery life of the projector could be better. I was able to watch a movie on it just fine, but it didn't have much extra.-The screen brightness drops a bit when on battery power. If you are projecting less than a 100" screen, you will be fine, but if you plan to go bigger than 90", you may want to use the power cord.When I was researching projectors, I had some findings that I wanted to share with you. These are not all specific to the MoGo Pro.-First of all, projector brightness marketing is a lie. The XGIMI MoGo Pro advertises 300 ANSI Lumens of brightness. I have a friend who got a projector that claimed 5500 Lumens of brightness. While you would think that my friends' projector would be 18 times brighter than mine, it's really not. And from what I have read, this is not an isolated case. Don't bother with the manufacturers' brightness numbers. If you want to see how bright a projector is, read the reviews.-Second, unless you plan on projecting on the side of your light-colored house, any projection size over 150" is basically pointless. I understand that a 300" screen sounds cool, but trust me, 98% of you don't need your projection to be that big, and will never use it that big. I'm not saying to not buy a projector that can go that big. I am saying to not buy a projector JUST because it can go that big.-Third, don't forget that screen size is measured diagonally. If you need to convert height & width to diagonal (or vice-versa), I would recommend finding an online calculator that can do that.-Fourth, don't forget the input. For the MoGo Pro, it has Android TV built-in, which will cover most of your needs, including YouTube, and all of the major streaming services that I know of. However, other projectors may not have Android TV, and before you buy, make sure that you also know how you will get a video to it. The worst thing is to get your shiny new projector and realize that you forgot to buy an HDMI Cable.-Fifth, some projectors may be able to go to big sizes, but the projector will have to be so far away from the screen that it is impossible indoors. Make sure the projector you choose can go to the screen size you want, at a distance that will work with your living space.-Sixth, if you have a light-colored wall, you probably don't need a screen, If you are considering a screen, hold a white sheet of paper up to the wall and compare how the projector on the paper looks to how the wall looks. That will give you a general idea of how much a screen will help.

title: Excellent picture, but has some annoying flaws.
date: Reviewed in the United States on May 26, 2020
body: I got this projector yesterday and I was really excited to use it, but that quickly turned to frustration. There are two main issues with the software1. You can't install Netflix directly from the Google Play Store, it is incompatible with this device. It sounds like the issue is a licensing problem with Netflix that XGIMI are trying to resolve, so maybe we'll get a fix for this in a future update. So, users are asked to download a third party app that installs a different build of the apk that works with the device. Doing this got me into Netflix, but the cursor would randomly stop responding when trying to scroll through the menus, but I could still select the item I was on. So, with that in mind, we decided to try watching Hulu. Which brings us to2. Hulu video freezes up every 10 seconds or so. The audio will continue to play, but the video will freeze for a few seconds, then it would catch up to the audio again, play normally for a few seconds, and then the video would freeze and repeat this process. Looking through some of the other comments I see this is a common problem for a few other users as well.SO, with those two options out of the picture, we tried using VLC Media Player to stream a movie I have on a network drive and this worked perfectly. The picture quality looks incredible, especially compared to the RIF6 Cube I had been using up until this point. The Harmon Kardon speaker was loud enough that we didn't need to use an external speaker, though I don't think it would hold up in a larger group setting. The remote is nice and easy to use, and it uses bluetooth so you don't have to actually point it at the projector for it to work.TL:DR - The hardware of the projector is solid and the picture quality is outstanding, but the software leaves a lot to be desired. Netflix and Hulu will give you issues if playing directly on the device, but it seems like all my problems will be remedied by simply plugging in a Chromecast and streaming through that instead.

title: I feel misled
date: Reviewed in the United States on May 30, 2020
body: First of all, if you don't have internet/wifi, DON'T buy this just thinking it'll be a projector. It NEEDS wifi and a google account before it'll even let you go to the projector mode. It seems to be 50/50 if it'll accept your router even if you do have wifi. Most Android TVs have a 'Skip' button on the wifi and google account setups, not so here. I couldn't tell you what the reasoning is behind that. The other thing that isn't mentioned in the product description that I feel is super important is that 3D DOES NOT WORK in four-corner keystone mode. This is a common thing with lower cost projectors and honestly I didn't think I had to ask here because this is not a low cost projector and not some knockoff company selling them, but apparently I really should have. I didn't really test anything else, after being so annoyed by the wifi not connecting at my house and not even being able to test it (And having to drag the thing to a friend's house on the random chance it might like his router, which for some reason it did) only to IMMEDIATELY find out that the most important thing to me is disabled when I'm projecting in the only mode I'll ever be projecting in because it's a PORTABLE projector. It's critical to be able to project from any angle and still have access to all the features I'm paying for. Also you can't set up the keystone correction until after you log in via the internet, so prepare to be pretty annoyed using the onscreen keyboard to type in wifi info and google accounts (Especially if you end up having to do it multiple times like I did) if you don't have a straight-on surface handy to set it up with.
